node.display_long_description:
The Thrill of the Fight is a down-to-earth VR boxing game focused on authenticity. Enter a virtual gym and battle a series of unique challengers with their own styles and techniques. Use timing and skill to land the knockout blow. Evade swings, land jabs, and block punches to become the king of the ring!

Room scale is required with a minimum supported play area size of 6.5ft by 6.5ft (2m by 2m). Please ensure your Guardian boundaries are set up properly for room scale and that you are willing to move and punch anywhere within and around the play area you have defined.

latest_supported_binary.change_log:
* Updated bHaptics SDK to latest release to fix pairing bugs
* Head hits now rumble more motors on the TACTAL mask to try to make the vibrations feel stronger
--------
* bHaptics pairing UI now shows an outline on devices that are available to pair
* Fixed bug with the bHaptics pairing menu where it would only show one device as being paired after coming back to the pairing menu after a fight, even though other devices were still paired
--------
* Added support for bHaptics devices. Use the new bHaptics option on the main menu to pair the hardware with the Quest. You'll need to allow TotF permission to access Bluetooth (shown as location permissions).
* Added support for Quest mixed reality capture.
* Added multiplier reset button to the Configuration quick-view panel to the right of the main menu. This button will only appear when you have the "Automatic Force Adjustment" enabled, and will let you quickly reset your multiplier if you feel it is stuck too low or if you are handing off the headset to another player.
* When the AI is lightly dizzed, it will only throw with its typical punch output when cornered. Previously, the AI would change from its lower punch output when significantly dizzy directly to its high punch output from being cornered. Switching to normal punch output under light dizziness helps the transition between the two.

nodes.title: Track your fitness in The Thrill of the Fight
nodes.body_text: Our players know that The Thrill of the Fight is a great way to have fun while getting an intense workout at home, but they often ask if there is any way to measure their physical activity while playing. We are excited to share that Oculus is now introducing this functionality with Oculus Move. This is a new platform feature that helps you track calories burned and physically active minutes as you play any game or app, including The Thrill of the Fight. The Oculus team has begun a gradual rollout today, so some Quest and Quest 2 users will already have access! Check your library for the Oculus Move app.

node.reviewDescription:
I am about to give a fairly "comprehensive" review, so a quick BLUF: I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loves boxing or is looking for a workout.

This game is the most authentic boxing simulator I have ever seen in or out of VR. This isn't a "chip away at a health bar" type fighting game, but a honest boxing sim. Three of my many favorite points of this game are:

PROS

- Weight class system. You use the heavy bag to determine your weight class. Your damage multiplayer on punches are based on this mechanic and it is a fantastic way to make it fun regardless of your physique.

- physics. The physics are dialed in spot on. Before you even get in a fight the speed bag, focus bag, and heavy bag demonstrate this very well.

- Opponent. The opponent's reactions, movements, and battle damage he takes are all realistic.


I want to be honest with this review, so there has to be a cons section. In reality I haven't found many in my few hours of playing it, so these will seem nit-picky:

CONS

 -Multiplayer. Multiplayer doesn't exist. I think it would be a fun addition, but honestly I think the amount of effort they put into this game was better spent on how spot on they got the single player rather than playing whack-a-mole chasing down all the headaches that would come with a multiplayer roll out. Maybe now that they made this game and are working on a sequel, they have the groundwork payed out for a future multiplayer stand alone game.

- Gloves. Again, super nit-picky, but I would like to see some variation on glove design. I am a huge fan of compact, blocky Mexican style gloves like anything made by Cleto Reyes and I my go to gloves vary from the 12-14 oz range. As someone who boxes welterweight, it is a bit disconcerting seeing myself holding these box honking 16oz gloves. It is a very minimal detail which I am sure has a lot to do with licensing, but it does throw off my visibility around my gloves by a slight amount.

OF NOTE FOR PEOPLE LOOKING TO PURCHASE THIS GAME:

Here are few things that might or might not appeal to you.

- This is not a "fighting game". If you want big flashy knockouts every time you land a combo or unrealistic fighting moves, this isn't the game for you. The point of this sim is authenticity, so even if you open up with your hardest hits and even score a knockdown you might find yourself genuinely winded and still get the tar knocked out of you. Just like if you were really boxing. Even if you land your hardest hits, where you land them is important. A conservative cross to the jaw is far more damaging than a full power jab to the forehead. HOWEVER, neither are particularly important if you don't score at least a knockdown. Sometimes you are better off saving your energy and going light. Boxing is often won on points, not flashy knockouts. The great this about this game is that it supports all styles of boxing, so do what works best for you.

- This game is a serious cardio workout. I am not talking about a VR "workout" like those reviewers that claim that beat saber is good cardio workout. This is common sense to anyone who has boxed before, but take it easy as you warm up, take a break when you need it, and drink water. You will get dehydrated otherwise. I also recommend a sweat towel, but that's just me.

FINAL NOTES

This game does the one thing that I was so scared it wouldn't. As a natural Southpaw, I was so afraid this game and it's mechanics would fall apart for anyone who isn't orthodox. I was afraid the AI wouldn't know how to respond to me like so many other VR games (looking especially hard at you, shooting sims). I was able to box comfortably and everything went great. Great game. A+
